landing_page.intro_content: Built on EOSIO. Delegated Proof of Stake is the future of smart-contract blockchains. We combine the blazing fast execution and scalability of EOSIO software with true decentralization that makes DPoS sustainable. Telos will have the most even money supply distribution of any blockchain. This token distribution improves governance so the network is more secure and ensures that the future of Telos is decided by its community. Telos has built the most advanced smart contract-controlled governance features of any blockchain.
landing_page.white_paper_content: Read the Telos white paper to judge for yourself.  We are out to create the best blockchain ever. Join us and build on Telos.

intro.heading: Downloads
intro.subheading: Download all the documents and tools that you need to join the Telos Network.

wallets.heading: Telos Wallets
wallets.subheading: Choose a wallet to store and trade your TLOS tokens.
wallets.sqrl_description: Sqrl is a fully functional light wallet designed for the TELOS blockchain. This application can be used to connect to a remote TELOS API endpoint to perform producer voting actions and common wallet commands.

white_paper.description: We are out to create the best blockchain ever - read the white paper to judge for yourself. Join us and build on Telos.

press_kit.description: Everything you need to know about Telos in one PDF.

style_guide.description: A style guide featuring Telos Foundation logos, color palettes and fonts for brand use.

voting_guide.description: A guide to executing all the Telos Foundation Board voting functions available on Sqrl wallet.

logos_icons.description: A package containing an assortment of file sizes and types for the Telos logo and icon.

banners.heading: Telos Article Splash Banners
banners.subheading: Splash Banner art for use in online articles about Telos.

intro.heading: Build Your Dapp on Telos
intro.subheading: The best network makes the best Dapps
intro_content: Telos uses the power of EOSIO to deploy fast, high-capacity dapps with no transaction fees for users. Telos is 100% code compatible with EOS but dapps cost 30X less to deploy on Telos, and Telos provides free user accounts. This makes Telos an ideal on-ramp for developers looking to build third-generation blockchain apps at a low price. Read more about the low cost of Telos dapp deployment.
intro.developers_content: Telos exists to provide a secure, stable, cost-effective network for deploying world class Dapps. Developers can expect affordable RAM prices and the ability to launch open-source or proprietary smart contracts with no transaction fees.
intro.dpos_content: The Telos network handles up to 5,000 transactions per second for blazing fast transactions and massive scalability. This means Dapps can reach a worldwide audience at the fastest average transaction speed of any blockchain—just 1.5 seconds!
intro.gov_content: Telos has a rich governance system from voting amendments to the user agreement, to ongoing block producer elections, to worker proposal funding and dispute resolution. No other blockchain offers the cohesive governance of Telos.
intro.tutorials_description: Learn how to build your Dapp on the Telos network.
intro.smart_contracts_description: Write smart contracts that perform basic Telos functions such as exchanging tokens and casting votes.

gigs.heading: Decentralized gig economies
content: Decentralized gig economies - Telos will lead the emergence of a new and more equitable gig economy; imagine the possibilities of the next Uber or Airbnb led by community ownership and a decentralized workforce.

currency.heading: Currency
content: A stable currency on Telos will open up possibilities to billions of people around the world who don't have access to bank accounts, providing the transparency and decentralization that is needed to prevent financial meltdowns such as the 2008 economic crisis or Venezuela's extreme currency inflation.

records.heading: Decentralized records and information
content: Corruption can be prevented when records are open, transparent and immutable. Information quality can be enhanced by aligned incentive and community efforts. Telos can support vital documents including home ownership registers, medical records, or the next community encyclopedia.

compatibility.heading: EOS Compatibility
content: EOSIO is currently responsible for half of all blockchain transactions and its development is expected to advance faster than older platforms like Ethereum and NEO. The Telos network runs the same EOSIO software as EOS, so Dapps written for EOS can run on Telos. No rewrite needed!

powerful.heading: Powerful performance for decentralized Dapp development
content: Telos facilitates incredibly fast and free transactions to establish a stable and affordable market for Dapp development. RAM supply will be scaled with actual usage in order to ensure affordability and prevent hoarding. Telos tokens have more than three times the resource utility of EOS, and developers will be able to purchase and stake resources such as CPU and bandwidth on behalf of users.

secure.heading: Secure and robust network
content: Telos expands on the EOS network by enforcing additional disclosure requirements and minimum requirements for Telos block producers, who must maintain a full and open testnet in order to support Dapp development. Nonfunctioning block producers are temporarily swapped out after missing just 30 minutes, as opposed to 3 hours on the EOS mainnet, so that developers encounter fewer pauses and problems without compromising security. Fair pay ensures all active and standby block producers are ready to produce at all times for maximum performance and stability.

proprietary.heading: Dapps can be proprietary code
content: Protect your intellectual property with Telos. Unlike EOS, Telos will not force all developers to open source their contract code. This allows commercial Dapp makers to keep other developers from simply copying their work.

decentralized.heading: Decentralized Governance and Arbitration
content: Telos has the most decentralized ownership of any blockchain existing today. No individual or entity will start with, or is likely to ever own, even one percent of the Telos blockchain. Telos’ decentralized voting system ensures that the blockchain is guided by the will of the community and the steady hand of the most competent block producers.

Telos will have a fully developed and ratified Network Operating Agreement and Telos Arbitration Organization (TAO) upon launch. These entities will ensure that conflicts are resolved in a timely manner so that developers can focus on Dapps instead of disputes.

intro.heading: Governance Overview
intro.subheading_one: Telos is a governed blockchain based on the EOSIO software. Like all DPOS (delegated proof of stake) chains, Telos has default governance built in. After observing other DPOS networks, the Telos blockchain founders decided to implement some safeguards to help protect the chain against collusion, hoarding, and ineffective BPs. Governance changes to Telos blockchain can only be implemented by Telos token holders through the referendum process.
intro.subheading_two: The Telos Blockchain is a decentralized, trustless system, where token holders have the power to come together and change the direction of the chain and the way it operates. Some often refer to DPOS chains as an online democracy, although in practice it is more akin to shareholders of a public company.
intro.subheading_three: A DPOS chain is particularly stable since approving referendum requires a significant amount of voters to approve a motion in order for any new initiatives or significant code changes to pass. It also allows for those that have a vested interest in the chain to have a voice and campaign for the changes they believe will be the most beneficial to the Telos ecosystem.

documents.heading: TELOS GOVERNANCE DOCUMENTS
documents.subheading_pone: Listed below is detailed documentation of the operating structures of the Telos blockchain, including on-chain governance, how to ratify or amend the governance documents by community voting, how to use the worker proposal system, and how to elect block producers and arbitrators. The definitions, rules, and procedures of Telos governance are contained in six documents that are recorded on-chain and modifiable by community vote (pro rata by TLOS token ownership). These documents are:

operating_agreement.long_description: This is the prime governing document on Telos describing the rights and responsibilities of becoming a member of the Telos Blockchain Network. It is required to opt-in to this agreement in order to access or use Telos. The TBNOA thoroughly defines all network parts and participants and describes governance actions such as electing block producers, amending the governance documents or making a worker proposal system submission. The TBNOA includes the other five governance documents by reference and each of them adopts its definitions and terms.

arbitration_rules.long_description: The Arbitration Rules & Procedures describes the entire process of arbitration on Telos - from filing a case to procedures for arbitration, to delivery of arbitral judges decisions to block producers for execution. They are also a community amendable core governance document on Telos.
arbitration_rules.short_description: Rules and procedures for arbitration on Telos

regproducer_contract.long_description: The 'regproducer' contract is used by any member desiring to become a block producer candidate to nominate themselves. The human-language terms of this contract set out the responsibilities and rules for block producer candidates.
regproducer_contract.short_description: Rules, responsibilities and representations of block producers

bp_minimums.long_description: The BP Minimum Requirements is a list of disclosures, practices, equipment and networking standards that block producer candidates must adhere to in order to serve. Failure to meet the minimum requirements disqualifies a BP from service until the omission is cured, regardless of how many votes the BP has acquired. Due to the newness of the network, these requirements are described in increasingly stringent phases which the block producers can vote to move between based on 2/3 + 1 voting.
bp_minimums.short_description: Minimum requirements to act as a block producer

regarb_contract.long_description: The 'regarb' contract is used by any member desiring to become an arbitrator candidate to nominate themselves. The human-language terms of this contract set out the responsibilities and rules for arbitrator candidates.
regarb_contract.short_description: Rules, responsibilities and representations of arbitrators

arbitrator_minimums.long_description: The Arbitrator Minimum Requirements is a list of disclosures, practices, equipment and networking standards that arbitrator candidates must adhere to in order to serve. Failure to meet the minimum requirements disqualifies an arbitrator from being assigned new cases until the omission is cured, regardless of how many votes the arbitrator candidate has acquired. Due to the newness of the network, these requirements are described in increasingly stringent phases. Election of arbitrators is unique to the Telos Blockchain Network.
arbitrator_minimums.short_description: Minimum requirements to act as an arbitrator

intro.heading: Frequently Asked Questions
intro.subheading: These FAQs do not provide legal advice and are for educational purposes only. You can find more information on the GitHub repository and Medium page.

faqs.question: What is Telos?
answer: Telos is a public or "open" blockchain network based on EOSIO software.

faqs.question: What is TLOS?
answer: TLOS is the name of the token that reflects ownership in Telos. A TLOS token is like an EOS token except that there will be around 3X fewer TLOS tokens than EOS.

faqs.question: What does the TLOS token entitle me to?
answer: Every TLOS entitles you to a certain amount of CPU and NET resources.  You can also purchase RAM (permanent storage on the blockchain) from the system using TLOS or sell back unused or recovered RAM to the system in return for TLOS. These resources are valuable and are how holders can use the network without paying any transaction fees. A user’s TLOS are also valuable as they are used for voting and soon will be used to lease out resources.

faqs.question: How do I get TLOS?
answer: There are two primary ways for an individual to get TLOS. First, TLOS was distributed to all users with addresses in the EOS genesis network snapshot who registered their ERC-20 EOS tokens as instructed by block one prior to June 1, 2018. If you had an EOS account during the EOS genesis launch, you have Telos. To access your tokens, simply use your original EOS genesis keys in a verified wallet that supports Telos. Verified wallets are listed here: Downloads.
The second way to get TLOS is to purchase TLOS from an exchange. See exchanges listing TLOS. Click the MORE menu item above and follow the Exchanges link for more information.

faqs.question: What exactly is the Telos genesis token distribution algorithm?
answer: Simply, it is that all Telos genesis addresses will receive the same number of tokens as their corresponding EOS addresses held in the genesis snapshot—up to a maximum of 40,000 tokens. There are a few exceptions to this policy: Addresses proven to have been stolen, phished, or misregistered, thereby depriving their rightful owners of them, were restored to new addresses controlled by their rightful owners; and new genesis tokens were created to compensate the launch group and establish the Telos Foundation.

faqs.question: Can I buy and sell TLOS tokens? What are they worth?
answer: Yes, as mentioned above, you may buy and sell TLOS on exchanges. The price is dynamic and subject to the free market.

faqs.question: What are the advantages of the Telos blockchain?
answer: 0.5 Second blocktimes, Advanced Governance and  Arbitration. Ready for real world business applications. Click the MORE menu item above and follow the respective links for more information.

faqs.question: What kind of examples can you provide me to illustrate the value of using the Telos Blockchain?
answer: Telos offers a highly advanced smart contract platform based on eosio technology. It's appropriate for almost anything; build a decentralized exchange, store company's stock holdings, legal contracts, AI, robotics, host a game economy with a currency and digital goods.
Here are some of the applications already on Telos:
Proxibots.io - Robot game with a provably fair scoreboard
Wordproof.io - A WordPress Plugin that will timestamp your posts to the blockchain.
EDNA - Control who has access to your DNA and how it is used, including who profits from that data.
Eosplaystation.com - Provably fair online casino
Telosplanet.one - Minecraft with digital economy

faqs.question: I heard exchange accounts cannot vote on the Telos blockchain network. If exchange addresses cannot vote, will my TLOS tokens be able to vote if they are currently on an exchange?
answer: Once tokens are off the exchange and in your own Telos wallet, you can vote them. Individual owners cannot vote their tokens held on exchanges. Preventing voting from exchange accounts keeps exchanges from voting with customer tokens, which is against the Telos operating agreement.

faqs.question: Is TLOS a security?
answer: No. The Telos blockchain raised no funds prior to launch and offered no promises regarding the TLOS token.

faqs.question: What does "public blockchain" mean?
answer: Public chains are decentralized meaning no one body has control over the network, ensuring the data can't be changed once validated on the blockchain. Anyone, anywhere, can use a public blockchain to input transactions and data as long as they are connected to the network.

faqs.question: Can Telos be run on a private chain? Is there help available to set a private chain up?
answer: The EOSIO software that Telos runs on is open source and can be downloaded on the Telos Github (linked at the top of this page). There is a group of blockchain professionals in the Telos ecosystem that has set up a consultancy to help those who need this service. They can be found here.

faqs.question: Telos is a DPOS blockchain. What is DPOS?
answer: Delegated Proof of Stake (DPOS) is a system where token holders vote for block producers, referendum, and other matters pertaining to the blockchain in question. The more tokens a user holds, the more weight their vote carries.

faqs.question: What are the differences between DPOS and POW?
answer: Delegated proof of stake is similar to a representative democracy in that voters cast votes for block producers, and then the top 21 elected block producers have the power to decide the direction of the chain. Proof of Work is a system in which computers compete against each other to solve puzzles, and get rewarded by the system for solving the puzzles presented. The better the machine in question is at solving puzzles, the more inflation it will collect.
Another difference is their energy efficiency. DPOS chains are thousands of times more efficient than traditional POW chains. You can read more about the EOSIO software’s energy efficiency here.

faqs.question: What is a block producer?
answer: A block producer runs the EOSIO software and validates transactions on the network. They are the server providers on the Telos blockchain. Users that hold TLOS vote for block producers and the 21 block producer candidates with the most votes become primary block producers for the chain.

faqs.question: Who is allowed to be a Telos block producer
answer: Anyone that runs the EOSIO software on the Telos blockchain can become a block producer candidate. The Telos Blockchain has a set of rules producers must comply with to be eligible for votes. Those rules can he found on the github linked at the top of the page.

faqs.question: How are block producers selected?
answer: Block producers are voted into their positions by holders of the TLOS token. These elections are ongoing, so producers can come in and out of positions quite often. This ensures that no block producer becomes too powerful within the Telos ecosystem.

faqs.question: How are Telos block producers paid?
answer: Telos has 21 Block Producers (BPs) and 30 standby BPs. The top 51 positions receive pay from the blockchain through inflation, with the top 21 block producers earning 2x those in position 22-51. Each block producer will be paid the same flat rate and each standby will be one half of that rate. All will receive pay deductions for missed blocks.

faqs.question: What kind of skills do I need to be a Telos block producer?
answer: Linux command line, experience as a systems administrator.

faqs.question: How do I register to become a block producer? What kind of infrastructure do I need to become a block producer? How do block producers help secure the network? Is there a forum I can join to read more about being a block producer?
answer: The answers to these and all other questions about becoming a BP on Telos can be found on the Telos Foundation Wiki.

faqs.question: Is there a forum I can join to learn about launching an application on the Telos blockchain?
answer: For resources and information join the Telos Application Development Group on Telegram.

faqs.question: What language can I use to code my smart contract?
Is there a way I can apply for funds to help me build my application?
answer: Yes. There are three ways that developers can receive grant type funds. The Worker Proposal System, Good Grants and Telos Foundation Grants.

faqs.question: Why should I launch my application on a public blockchain?
answer: In most cases it will be far cheaper to launch your application on Telos as opposed to setting up your own private chain. In order to have a truly immutable chain you need a large community and trusted block producers who are vested in the network. The Telos Blockchain Network provides this for you.

faqs.question: Can developers make their code proprietary?
answer: Yes, there is NO requirement on Telos to make your code proprietary open source.

faqs.question: What if Telos users don’t want to use proprietary software on the blockchain?
answer: Each smart contract will designate if portions of its code are proprietary. Telos members will be able to choose whether or not they wish to work with proprietary smart contracts or only open source contracts.

intro.heading: Arbitrator Program
body: The Telos Network is the world’s first governed blockchain with arbitrators elected by its members. We are looking for legal professionals from around the world to help us build this system into the model for all future blockchain governance and arbitration.

Arbitrators may be individuals, teams, or firms who nominate themselves by executing the regarbitrator contract. Arbitrators are selected by the votes of TLOS token-holders and are paid arbitration fees in TLOS. At launch, this page will hold the campaign statements of every arbitrator candidate to facilitate voting. At present, the site shows sample statements and statements from any who notify us of their intent to campaign.

documents.title: Telos Arbitration Process Document
description: This document outlines how the arbitration of disputes and interventions to change account or contract values will be administered on the Telos Network.

documents.title: Telos Arbitrators Minimum Requirements
description: All arbitrators must meet minimum requirements to ensure that they are qualified to settle disputes on the Telos Network.

documents.title: regarbitrator human-language contract
description: All arbitrators must agree to fulfill the terms outlined in this smart contract.

contact.heading: If you are interested in becoming an arbitrator on the Telos Network, please contact us.

elected_arbitrators.name: Blake Lagarde
statement: Having received a B.S. Biological Sciences (2007) and a B.S. Nursing (2010) from Louisiana State University, Blake Lagarde’s journey towards arbitration candidacy is a unique one. He has spent his decade long professional career as a Registered Nurse, presently at Children’s Hospital in his home town of New Orleans. What he lacks in traditional law practice is made up by first hand experience with and a passion for EOS and Telos (and Ethereum by proxy) blockchain token recovery. Nearly 2 weeks after the EOS Genesis Snapshot and Mainnet launch, Blake personally created the now 1,300 member EOS Lost Non-Compromised (Genesis) Key Group on Telegram--an EOS 911 partner. He has also served as an administrator for the 2,200 member EOS 911, known together with the former as the "EOS Lost Key Community." He has led the effort to find a solution for those with lost non-compromised genesis keys (as well as some fringe cases). He penned the EOS Lost Key Petition which has garnered the support and signature of over 1,700+ individuals. Through Blake’s personal outreach the Lost Key movement has also received endorsement or support from over 30 EOS Block Producers, many of whom fill the ‘Top 21’ today. Because of the work in and commitment to the EOS Lost Key community, he was approached by Douglas Horn to join the Telos Launch Group (TLG) with a focus on token recovery.

Per Douglas Horn, as a member of the TLG, "[Blake has] been an important part of [telos launch group]. [Blake] brought a lot of credibility for us in the Lost Key community at a time when people still did not know whether they could trust us. For those who do not know, Blake played a key role in getting the ECAF to reach out to their entire email list about Telos key recovery. And he diligently worked with people who were having problems [with telos token recovery] He also prevented a lot of thefts from people testing our process."

From pioneering the EOS lost key effort, to being the first EOS holder to receive a lost key claim ruling from the ECAF, and personally working on telos token recovery support and validation; the next logical step in Blake’s intimate journey through the world of cryptocurrency and lost or stolen private keys is to become an official Telos Arbitrator.  To date, Blake has already assisted 160 individuals recover their 300,000+ telos tokens.  He looks forward to the future as an opportunity to continue to help those with blockchain issues on a more official basis.

When Blake is not advocating for those with lost keys, his time is spent with his life partner of ten year, Dr. Anneliese Boettcher (PhD Neuropsychology), and their two beautiful mutts Hubie (in picture) and Sula.  When Blake and Anna are not at a music festival or catching a local artist play a show, they are both active members in NOLA’s Mental Health Advocacy Sources, such as the Brett Thomas Doussan Foundation, with a focus on suicide prevention.

elected_arbitrators.name: Justin Yashouafar
statement: Justin.arb is owned 100% by Justin Yashouafar.
Justin Yashouafar  is  a Managing  Partner at  Blockhead Capital,  a blockchain  and cryptoasset focused investment fund.   He  is  also  a member  of  the EOSVibes  block producer.

Justin attended  the University  of  Southern  California, where he  earned  a Bachelor  of  Science in  Business Administration. He  later continued his education at  UCLA School  of  Law,  where he  earned  his Juris Doctor degree with  a specialization  in  Business  Law.  Following law school, Justin  practiced full  time  as  a transactional attorney  at  a large United  States  based law firm, where he counseled and advised family  offices,  institutional funds, and publicly  traded  investment  trusts, as  well  as  seed  and growth  stage companies including WeWork, Cross Campus, and Mitú.

Justin first learned about and began researching Bitcoin in  2011. In  the summer  of 2016, together  with  several investment  banking peers,  he  developed a thesis  to invest  in  Bitcoin as  a hedge against sovereign currency  collapse, potential hyperinflation, and a mounting  global  debt  crisis. After deploying capital based on this  thesis, Justin  fell  down  the crypto  rabbit  hole  when  he  learned about the industry-shifting potential of  smart-contract  enabled blockchain  platforms.

In November  2018, realizing the issues  with  the EOS first chain’s constitution, Justin drafted and proposed  a new EOS Constitution to the community.  Justin  has been involved  with  eosio blockchains since inception and is  excited to  work  to  make Telos one of  the best  iterations  of  eosio – with  the goal  to  make  it  the best  platform to  launch  and run successful  dApps.

elected_arbitrators.name: Chijioke Ilochonwu
statement: "My name is Chijioke Ilochonwu. I am a Telos Blockchain Arbitrator. I am the owner of Nobles, a shipping and logistics company that cordinates the movement of goods and services overseas. I hold a bachelors degree in Pure and Industrial Chemistry. I also authored the book, "You Shall Know the Truth About Tithing," which you can preview and purchase on Amazon @ https://www.amazon.com/shall-know-truth-about-tithing/dp/0989356701. Originally from Nigeria, now a naturalized citizen of the United States, my journey to who I am and what I have become today is because of my faith and personal relationship with Jesus Christ who has carried me since I committed my life to Him during my last year of college in 1999. This definitely sustained me through the first few trying years when I arrived in the United States with only $20 in my pocket."

"I am known as FINANCIALFREEDOMCJ from my Youtube channel @ https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaoILL2Xi3oAZak0daSi0Rw with over 250 subscribers. When I discovered the vision of the Telos Blockchain and read the white paper several times, I was sold! This was the vision I had in my mind for the EOSIO space, a fully decentralized, functioning governance system. My knowledge, passion, and excitement for the Telos Blockchain caused me to author more than 30 articles and many videos about Telos which can be viewed @
  • https://trybe.one/user/6540
  • https://www.reddit.com/user/financlfreedomcj
  • https://twitter.com/financfreedomcj
  • https://medium.com/@financialfreedomcj
  • https://steemit.com/@financlfreedomcj
  • https://whaleshares.io/@financlfreedomcj
  • https://financialfreedomcj.quora.com
  • https://deals.weku.io/@financlfreedomcj

"I am one of the very few community members outside the Telos Launch Group to earn the highest amount of Telos tokens (TLOS) in the Telos Community Rewards Pool (TCRP) and also the highest amount available of the highly coveted Telos Foundation Voting Tokens (TFVT) for the Telos Community Rewards Pool (TCRP). I was also a Telos Foundation nominee. I bring my vast experience of the various facets of the Telos project to Telos Arbitration."

elected_arbitrators.name: Mikko Ohtamaa
statement: Mikko is chief technical officer, open source advocate, blockchain developer.
Mikko brings his expertise of IT forensics and in-depth blockchain understanding to the arbitration panel.

Mikko is the CTO of TokenMarket, a crowdfunding platform. Before Mikko was the CTO of LocalBitcoins, a peer-to-peer bitcoin exchange. Mikko has extensive experience of resolving user disputes, gathering evidence, doing the technical investigation and chain analysis on cryptocurrency fraud and heists. Mikko is familiar with Financial Conduct Authority (UK), Finance Service Commission (Gibraltar) and Financial Action Task Force recommendations. Furthermore, Mikko keeps himself up to date international discussion of the legal status of cryptocurrencies and digital ledger technology.

Mikko has a long career in software development that he started with early mobile software in 1999. Later, Mikko moved to cryptography based systems and started with Bitcoin in 2013, and Ethereum in 2016. He has been contributing to Ethereum foundation projects and now looks to help Telos Foundation.  Before Mikko served in Plone Foundation, one of the oldest open source foundations, and helped to established Python Finland, a user group of open source developers.
Mikko holds MSc. in Industrial Engineering and Management from the University of Oulu.

elected_arbitrators.name: Marc-Roger Gagné
statement: Marc-Roger Gagné is a prolific Data Governance Advocate who resides in Ottawa, Canada. Throughout the span of nearly two decades, Marc-Roger has been dedicated to providing top-notch policy advice for government and corporate clients alike. He is a member of the Board of Directors of the Privacy and Access Council of Canada since 2010 and a Member of the International Association of Privacy Professionals (817631). Additionally, he holds membership at the Compliance, Governance & Oversight Council, the Law Society of Upper Canada.

Marc-Roger’s accreditations are many. In 2011 he was recognized as a Master Access and Privacy Professional (MAPP), the highest designation in the Privacy  community. He also holds accreditations as a CIPP, CIPP/G, CIPP/C, Certified Cyber Threat Analyst (CCTA), Certified Cyber Intelligence Investigator (CCII), Certified Human Trafficking Investigator (CHTI) and Certified Cyber Threat Forensic Investigator (CTFI). His key competencies lie in Litigation, Privacy, Breach Management and Training Programs, Policy Development, Information Management, Informational Technology, Data Analytics.

Combining his vast knowledgebase along with his integrity, Marc-Roger is a well-recognized and respected professional who has integrated numerous innovative strategies into everything that he does in the privacy, data protection, and legal services fields.

elected_arbitrators.name: Mariela Josefina Mejias de Coronado
statement: Venezuelan nationality, resides in a town of the beautiful Capital City Barcelona, Anzoategui state, a city with a history of heroes and liberators of great relevance for my country. I consider myself an excellent Arbiter of Telos, for being a woman who practices justice, love of neighbor, truth, respect, honesty, wisdom, humility, knowledge, with the vision of helping others, directing them, motivate them in the right way, the way of love and prosperity.

Systems Engineer by profession dedicated to Project Training and Consulting, Systems Analyst in the Higher Education area in the Faculty of Engineering at the Northeastern University of Gran Mariscal de Ayacucho in Venezuela.

Knowledge in Psychology Behavioral Therapist "LOGOTHERAPY", in Barcelona -Anzoategui, University Consortium: Central University of Nicaragua (UCN), National Academic Coordination, Universidad Cristiana del Sur. March 2009.

Brief familiarization about Telos Arbitration rules such as: Limitation of Authority, Default Arbitration forum, Alternative Arbitration Forums, No Responsibility of the Referee, All Final Decisions, Classes of Cases, Inclusion of Precedents, Identification of Additional Accounts, Scope of the Decision, Execution of the Decision, and Basic knowledge about the mechanics of Blockchain and EOSIO; The most powerful infrastructure for decentralized applications.
NOTE: "I do not have any Telos currently."

Reflection: "Because there is only one God, and only one mediator between God and men, Jesus Christ man. 1 Timothy 2: 5. If we want to be a good Telos Referee, let us follow the example of Our Lord Jesus Christ, he is the master par excellence of arbitration, there is no one like him. God continue to bless you and the love of Christ shine in your heart!"
Ing. Mariela Mejias

elected_arbitrators.name: Sean M. King (金世翔)
statement: Overview:

• CEO of EOSex Exchange (already listing and assisting several Telos projects)
  • 10yrs Legal & Governance Experience
  • Special Blockchain Advisor to Taiwan Congress
  • Core Member of Taiwan Blockchain SRO (Self-Regulatory Organization)
  • Fluent in English and Mandarin Chinese
  • Believe in open, transparent, and fair blockchain

"I have over 10yrs of legal and corporate governance experience, and am currently CEO of EOSex, a crypto exchange that already lists several Telos and EOS-based projects, so I am already familiar with Telos projects, and very active and well-known among the Telos community. I am also currently special blockchain advisor to Taiwan congress, a core steering committee member for the Taiwan blockchain SelfRegulatory Organization (SRO), and a member of the working group that actually drafted the governance rules, the 'Code of Conduct', for exchanges under the Taiwan SRO. I am also fluent in English and Mandarin Chinese."
"My governance Philosophy"

"I firmly believe in a transparent and decentralized blockchain where all disputes are handled in an open and 'innocent until proven guilty' manner; where people should not be blacklisted without due process, as this goes against the spirit of blockchain which rejects arbitrary exclusion that we see in so many other parts of society; where users should have free access to their own funds, tokens, and accounts without interference unless clear evidence has been presented to the contrary, and unless the person in question has had a chance to dispute that evidence in a fair and open manner."

elected_arbitrators.name: Chukwuemeka, Ukamaka Patience
statement: My name is Chukuemeka, Ukamaka. I am from Anambra State which is the Eastern part of Nigeria, but I live and work in the Capital, the Northern part of the Country. For the past 8 Years, I have worked as the Warehouse Supervisor for an International Pharmaceutical company. I hold a bachelor’s degree and currently running a Post Graduate Diploma in Logistics & Supply Chain Management and Warehousing & Materials Management from College of Supply Chain Management Nigeria.

Through my extensive warehouse management experience spanning almost a decade, I have developed strong expertise in successfully overseeing logistics, medical, and inventory control while collaborating with multicultural, diverse staff to maximize productivity, efficiency, and overall warehouse performance. Through my experience, I have become adept in ensuring adherence to organizational goals and requirements while facilitating streamlined warehouse operations.

All my life, I’ve have always love to serve which is why I have made myself available and approachable to others in order to assist in any way that I can be of help. When I was newly introduced to the Blockchain, I loved it especially the dynamics of it. Steemit was the platform account that I created. At first, I had difficulties trying to fit into the platform for the first three months. Then, I met the founder of steemchurch in a person of Sirknight who was so helpful in helping young steemians find their feet.

This actually motivated my friends and me in creating a community account where newbies are tutored, nurtured, and within a short period of time, we were able to help about 300 newcomers on the platform. We were also able to go round the states in Nigeria, talking to universities students about the platform and Blockchain.

The nature of my offline job has also contributed a lot in helping to build my inter-personal relationship. As a Supervisor heading six states, the primary aim of my job is to make sure our customers are satisfied. This I have achieved by prompt delivery and making sure that their complaints are been well handled.

Serving as Telos Arbitrator will give me the opportunity to showcase the skills that I’ve learned over these years in the course of my job. My skills include: commitment: actively contributes to achieving organizational goals; honest; hard-working; diversity: respects others and values their diverse perspectives and contribution; integrity: acts in a manner consistent with the organizational core values and organizational principles; accountability: takes responsibility for my own action and delegated work; ability to interact in a helpful manner; time management; decision making and problem-solving skills; excellent personal communication skills, in written and verbal English; team player.

I have always been a strong believer of the Blockchain and have invested time, energy, and money to it. I have also wanted to be involved in a community whose goal is to better the quality of life of humanity and I would state here that it would be an honor to join the Telos community. I know I will find fulfillment from having an opportunity to serve as Arbitrator because for me, blockchain is the future!
